The ICC World Twenty20 2014: Predictions

23/03/2014

As the ICC World Twenty20 starts to gather pace, Lewis Hill and Beth Jakubowski make their tournament predictions.

Image by

By undefined undefined

This year, cricket fans across the globe will be treated to three weeks of unforgettable action. The most exciting format of the game returns to the forefront of international cricket as Bangladesh host the ICC World Twenty20. Lewis Hill and Beth Jakubowski make their predictions for this year's tournament. Winner Lewis says: India It's difficult to choose a winner at the moment, usually because one of the pre-tournament favourites is often eliminated during the Super 10 stage. However, I'm going to play it safe and say India. For me, across the board India are a devastatingly good team. They have a strong leader in MS Dhoni, a very capable all-rounder in Yuvraj Singh, a must for a truly world class T20 team. Furthermore, they have a good bowling attack with players such as Mohammed Shami and Ravindra Jadeja but they also have a run machine in Virat Kohli, if he continues to play to the high standards he has recently set, then he will surely set the tournament alight! Beth says: West Indies Crash, bang, wallop, the words that define T20 cricket and incidentally, define the West Indies team. Since the 2012 World Cup the West Indies' credentials have improved dramatically, they've proved that their destructive batsmen are now backed up by a solid and dependable bowling unit. Darren Sammy is a capable and inventive captain, he's not afraid to go on the offensive, which works brilliantly in the shorter forms of the game. It's been a long time since the Windies have had a side to boast about, but with Chris Gayle, Sammy, Dwayne Bravo and Marlon Samuels in their ranks they have a team and a batting line up that all bowling attacks should fear. Highest Run Scorer Lewis says: Virat Kohli It's no secret that this man can bat, but in the shorter formats of the game he is phenomenal. He may not have quite hit the dizzying heights of Chris Gayle yet but in recent years he has been the Indian batsman to watch in the IPL. His international T20 average is impressive, nearly 35 and he is no stranger to some big hitting. It was a toss-up between Kohli and Gayle but I think Kohli runs will propel India to the trophy so he is my tip for most runs. Beth says: Chris Gayle T20 cricket is where Chris Gayle shines; he's got the whole package; the swagger, the shots and the guile. Innovation isn't needed when you're as powerful as Gayle, he doesn't have a weak area and captains consistently struggle to set a field to him. Once Gayle gets geared up, he's pretty much unstoppable and instead of trying to get him out, teams go on the ultra defensive against him. That's the sign of a truly destructive batsman. Leading Wicket Taker Lewis says: Lasith Malinga This was the easiest one for me. Malinga is quite simply, the best. At the death there is no other bowler that can match him and his blistering pace and spine tingling accuracy have left many a batsman quaking in their boots. His slower balls are a handy part of his arsenal but his yorkers are the envy of many a pace bowler. The fact that this man can take wickets at both the start and the end of an innings and do so consistently and for as long as he has been doing, leads me to tip him as leading wicket taker. Beth says: Lasith Malinga As my colleague has already alluded to, Malinga is just awesome. The Yorkers, the swing, the line and length, Malinga is just phenomenal. There is no better death bowler in the world than Malinga, the fear he imparts on batsmen by his presence alone does half the job for him. He can single-handedly win a game for Sri Lanka and has done numerous times in the past, he's easily the most destructive pace bowler in the shorter form of the game and I'm backing him to continue his electric form. One to Watch Lewis says: Aaron Finch It remains to be seen how well Australia will do in this year's competition, they could well be the dark horses but I would argue that they'll do well if this man can deliver. Aaron Finch has established himself as a big hitter and as an England fan I have been trying to forget his 156 at the Rose Bowl last year for quite some time! His shots are clinical and decisive but he hits them a lot harder than any other player on the T20 scene at the moment. If he carries on his lethal form, then he could well be the one to watch not just in this year's tournament but throughout 2014. Beth says: Moeen Ali Considering England's recent form choosing an England player as a one to watch is perhaps unwise. But Ali has looked in decent touch and has proved that he's worth his place. He has some big shots but he's got a deft touch as well, he can work the field well and he's gaining a lot of confidence. If England do reasonably well in this tournament Ali will be one of the main reasons. Injuries have plagued England with Stokes and Wright already gone, but the young guns might just surprise people. I also think that England would be mad not to play Craig Kieswetter, it was ridiculous that they didn't have him in the original squad; he could also be a player to keep an eye on. After all, he won England the World Cup in 2010, and that is nothing to be sneered at. Dream Team In batting order Lewis's Team Shane Watson (AUS), Chris Gayle (WI), Virat Kohli (IND), David Warner (AUS), Aaron Finch (AUS), Yuvraj Singh (IND), AB de Villiers (WK/C) (SA), Stuart Broad (ENG), Sunil Narine (WI), Dale Steyn (SA), Lasith Malinga (SRI) Beth's Team David Warner (AUS), Chris Gayle (WI), Marlon Samuels (WI), JP Duminy (SA), Virat Kohli (IND), M.S Dhoni (WK/IND), Darren Sammy (C/WI), Stuart Broad (ENG), Dale Steyn (SA), Lasith Malinga (SL), Saeed Ajmal (PAK)
